ask'd the sage, when wandering afar
In search Of Wisdom's bright and shining star,
What's wisdom HE exclaim'd with fearful eyes,
"The fear of Gods the Wisdom Of the wise"
ask'd the rainbow's changing tnts Of light.
The glorious harbinger Of mercy bright
Aud badc me lull the fearful heart of man."
ask'd the ocean-snd its ceaseless tide
In hollow murmurs to my voice replied
Behold my swelling waves, their ebb and flow.
The hand of Wisdom marks how far they'll 60"
Then pursued the pure, the golden sun,
And found him nearly when his course was done;
90 stay me not" he cried, "check not my pace,
IT'S Wisdom's work run the heavily race!"
ask d the stars 10 track me Wsdoms way,
In The high heav'n Of glory where they lay;
"'Tis Wisdoms path" they cried "thx we have trod,
The path to Wisdom is-the will Of God %
ask'd the moon, the moon that shone afar,
In her pale light within her crescent car
:" Wisdom is knowledge of the hand divine
That bade me be-and PLACID me here to shine"
The silver spheres caught up the heavily song,
Echo'd through endless space it rol'd along;
Angels reJoc'd and hll'd with holy fires,
Tun'd unto Wisdom all their golden Tyres.
+" Wisdoms he influence brightly glowing,
From The Almighty's glory ever flowing!
tn unspotted mirror of is power and might,
The radiance of the everlasting light"
Then earthborn man attune thy sacred yrcp
And join ting chorus of the heavily choir,
L. praise to the great tribune God above,
Whose Willis Wisdom, and whose rod is love.
ROwENA.
WHAT rs WISDOM ?

AS body OF troops passed in review before Bona
parte at the Carousel, his horse became so unruly
that his hat fell off in his exerions to restrain it..
A young soldier, who happened to be near him.
picked up the hat and presentedit it to him. Thank
you captain said Napolean. In what regiment,
sire?' said The young man. A few days after. the
young man, with whose answer Bonsparte was
much pleased, was unexpectedly raised by brevet
to the rank Of captain Of the imperial Guard.

and new fur hat He went in company with apprentice
belonging TO Peter A. Humphreys, named John Hail. All
persons are warned not TO harbor or employ him.


THOMAS MOORE.
Wilmington, Jan. 10, 1897. 21-4t

EVE.


ByALApr OF NEWPORT, RI.
II is the tender twilight hour,
And glimmering through yon russell bower,
The dying ligh, is seen,
Giving family golden tinge
To the rich mines that deeply fringe
Its Ia'ices of green.
The mellow whistle still is heard,
Of that same dear familiar bird,


We used to love so we'll;
Fer had known the parting pain
d bliss of meeting thee again.


My own dear Rosabee
Ah Love thou never canst forget
When on the green our hamlet met,
And merry pipes were played;
How from the dance we stole away,
And tremblingly led the way


Toyonder lovely shade.
We reach'd the bower, the moon-beams fell
Full on my lovely Rosabelle,


Making the fair more fair.
Like vines round marble pillars hung,
So round her polish'd neck were Aung
The sunny wreaihs OF hair.
Her angel face was tnrnd aside
The blush Of innoc, nee TO hide,


That DER her features stole.
We ne'er before had been alone.
Nor had ever dared TO own


The love that fill'd my soul.
Oh! tell me why in that strange hour,
Beauty had such mysterious po@er'
For though convsed with fears---
With passion not TO be rerressed.
threw myself upon thy breast,


And told my love in tears;
Thou vert subdned; heard thy sohs--
felt thy bcsom's answering throbs--
Thy tears were mixed with mine.
We knew that every doubt was done
Our hearts had melted into one.


On feelings holy shrine
But when the shock that open threw
Our bosoms, to each others view,
In gentle numbers died
The morn Of love--'twas heaven to trace,
just opening in thy besming face,


In all its blushing pride.
Then, Rosabelle. for memory's sake
Our way to thai same bos ser we'll lake,
That saw loves roscate dawn;
Fer this is Courtship's latest eve,
And the. our bridal wrea'hs we'll weave,
Togrsce the coming morn.
All nature seems our bliss to share.
Spirits Of joy are in the air.


They wave their rainbow wings,
And shed, on his auspiciuos night
glow Of pure Elysisn light,


Ger all created things. ROWENA.

TIE LOVER TO HIS MISTRESS, ON THE BRIDAL


EVE.

Roger. where was If'-At Kenwyn, during di-
vine service, two dogs, one of which the par
sons, were 6gh,ing at the west end Of the Church.
The parson who was then reading the second les
son. rushed out to part them; and on his return,

Convention; and conformobly TO our annual custom,


tins week make few remarks relative to that


never to be forgotten Assembly. We agree that
on some accounts this task is rather unpleasant :
but we conscentiously believe that proper regard


Tor those republican principles which we have always


cherished. requires the performance at our hands.


We are also ready to admit that many ot the MEM
bers and promoters Of the Hartford Convention pos
sessed talents and integrity and other qualities which


rendered them useful and respectable ctIzeps and
We are willing that their friends should dwell on
their virtues much and az often as they please,
tor we do not undertake TO arragn any thing
than their conduct as connected with this political
project But this we have done, and still do, be-
cause NC have always believed that the Hartford
Convention was . party measure, and INTENDED to
sustain the waning Cause OF federalism; because it
was calculated n its results to be rpinous TO the
peace, unity. and prosperity OF our county and
because the fair fame Of Connecticut, our native
State, was sued by being the spot selected Tor The
Convention to assemble in.


In order therefore that the present generation (f
there are any whose minds are not made up) anc
posterty may be enabled to form correct Judgment
on this subject, We sgaia enumerate some OF the
reasons which led us q, the time, and which have
continued from that day to this to coDst ain US TO
censure this 6old and dangerous scheme. 1t had


long been fore'od BY the emssaries oil Grea' Britain,
that, on the happening Of certain e-en's. Conyen-
tion. like that which assembled at Hartford, would
be held. Those events happened, and the predicted
Convention was hcId-These same cmissaries fore
told that in should be declared against
Engla' d, there would be great opposition to that
war in New England. and Massachusetts would take
he lead in that opposition War was declared and
great opposition arose in the New Eng land States =;
aud the legislature of Massachusetts gave the tone
The ncghboiing States. The members and friends
Of the Convention were the ssders OF the federal
party, who not only opposed the then administration
ut The general government, but they we're strongly
suspected Of being friendly to the British govern
mvni These men had previousl. declared that the
Constitution Of The United States had tailed TO
cure the objects for which formed iney l,ied
to rmbafrass the ed inistraon by ext ring them
selves to transfer the management oil ,he
u the general government 10 the Stale govern ments;
they would not rejoice al he defeats oi the enemy.
nor would they rejoice a. he victories gained by
own army and navy They held the Convention in
secret. and With closed doors and al the time when
the enemy were com ting depredstIons at Ha.re-
de-Grace n.saul'ing Baltimore, pilaging and burn


ing Washington. ard preparing their expedition
against New Oleans; in short, al the very time when


the whole Atlantic coast was threatened with fire
and sword, and the whole northern frontier wa, an
noyed by the ravaees of the enemy and heir In
dian allies. The Convention ton, was held during
war which had been unayoldably declared For tbs
protection OF the lives and liberty Of portion Of our
cixens and for the protection of invaluable rights,
and vast amount of property .whi' war has been
emphaiically styled the second war ol Independence.
And a. every war, however just, necessariIy brings
with it great and distress. this crisis -ezed
by the ederass to regain the standing places, and
influence, which they losing, and force the
government to make a dishonorahle peace. Such
must have been the views Of the friends Of he Con-
venton, for let never be forgotten that the objects
Tor which it was held were mt OBJ all ed. nor have
they since its dissolution made any mpts OBJ
tain the IN but their objec's given over, and
the prospects OF these aspirants vanished soon
the news OF honorable peace reached our shores.
The effects produced by the Convention we he
encouragement Of the enemy, and the sggrava'lon
Of the distresses OF our own citizens. In conciu-
sion, we do not deny that our attention has been
the steadily turned to this subject fof the last
twelve years, because We have always viewed it as
one Of those occur'en' es in the course OF events,
which has worderiul.y tended to put up republic ans
and to pui down federasts and at this time oil day,
who will not admit that this is it should be. for it
seems to have been Of those strong instances in
which much good has come out OF great evil,
but thanks to be given to the friends of the
Convention for that ard all we ask is, that in view
oil the foregoing remarks, every reader should can
didy form such an opinion as III: whole facts and
circumstances warrant


Literary Bargain.- When Fielding had finished
his novel OF Tom Jones, being much distressed he
sold il to an obscure bookseller lor 25l. ON condcn
Of being paid certain given dsy. In the mean
time, he showed the manuscript 10 Thomson, the
Poet, who was Immediately struck Wi its great
merit, and advised Fielding by all means to get ree
from the bargain. which he did without much diff
Guilty, as the bookseller was not capable OF estimat-
ing the value OF his pu chase Thomson recon-
mended the work to Andrew Miller and the parties
met at 4 tavern over beef steak and bottle. Mill
Ter began with saying, Mr.. Fis.dng. always de-
rmine affairs Of this sort at once, and ever
change nv offer, | viii not give one fat thing

eu OF pigeons, as letter carriers s by Ovid. IN h
4" Meamor phoses," who tell Us that Taurssthene
by pigeon stained with purple, gave notice oi b
having been victor at the Olympic games on III
very same day to his father at Egins.


When the city Of Ptolemais. in Syria, was invest
ed by the French and Venitans, and it read
to fall into their hands, they observed pigeon 6y
ing over them, and Immediately conjectured tina,
was discharged with letters TO the garrison On thi
the whole army raising loud shout. SO confounde
the poor erial post, that it fell to the ground
ON being seized, letter was found under its wings
from the Sultan, in which he assured The garrison
that he would be with them in three days, with al
army sufficient to raise the SIEGE" For this let
ter the brssgess substituted another to this purpose
that the garrison must see to their safety, 70
the Sultan had such other ssirs pressing him, tina
it was impossible for him to come to their succour;'
and with this false intelligence they let the pgeor
nee on his course. The garrison. deprived by th
decree OF all hopes Of relief, Immediately surrender
ed. The Sultan appeared on the third day, a:
promised, with q powerful army, and was
little mortified to end the city already In the hands
Of the Christians.


Carrier pigeons were again employed, but with
better success at the siege Of Leyden, in 1875 The
garrison we're, by means Of the Information thu:
conveyed to thcm induced to stand out, till the enc
my, desparing Of reducing the place, Withdrew
On the seige being raised the Prince of Orange or
dered that the pigeons who had rendered such es-
sentipl service should be maintained at the public
expense and that at their Death they should be EN-
bsmed and preserved in the town house, as 6
perpetual token OF gratitude.


In the East. the employment Of pigeons for the
conveyance ofletters is still very common. parties
lsrly in Syria, Arabia, and Egypt. Every Basha~
has generally . basket full # them sent him from
the grand serago, where they bred, and in case
o! any insurrection or other emergency. he is en-
abed, by letting loose two more OF these extraor
dinary messengers convey intelligence to The gov
rrnment long before it could be possibly obtained by
other means.


The diligence snd speed with which these feath
cred messengers wing their course is cxtraor binary
From the instant OF their liberatioD their flight
directed through The clouds at an immense heigh,
to the place OF their destination. They believed
to dart onward 10 a straight line and never descend
except when a. loss for breath, and then they art
to be seen, commonly at dawn Of day, lying on hci
aoks on the ground, with their bills open, suckir.
in with hss,y avidi'y the dew Of the morning. o
their speed the instances related almost incred
Bile.


The Consul of Alexandra daily sends despatche
by these means TO Aleppo in hours, though cour
ers occupy the whole day and proceed with the ut
most expedition from one town to the other.


Some years ago gentleman scot carrier pigeon
from London by the stage cosrh. to bis friend ir
ST. Edmonsbury, together with q note, de,ring tina
the pigeon Two days after their arrival there nigh
be thrown up precisely when the town clock struck
nine in the morning. This was done accordingly
and the pigeon arrived in London, and Rew to the
Bull Inn, Biahopgate street, into the lot,, and
there shown at half an hour past eleven o'clock
having flown seventy two miles in two hours and a
half.


AT Antwerp. in Isl9 one OF the thirty two pigeons
belenging to that city. who had been conveyed to
London, and here let loose, made the transit back
being distance in direct line Of one hundred and
eighty miles, in six hours.


Il 10 through the attachment OF the animals to the
place Of their birth. and particularly to the spot
where they had brought up their young, that they
are thus rendered useful 10 mankind.


When young one flies very hard at home, as il
comes TO its iul strength it is carried in basket
otherwise about half mile from home, and there
turned out-after this. il is carried mile, and ther
two four eight, ten twenty, &C. till at length vii
return from the furthermost parts Of the country.

In an action for an assault and battery, il was
deemed proper to ascertain the size Of a certain
stone, with which il was alleged the battery was
committed. For this purpose a witness was called
to the stand, and the following brief report Of his
examination will show how perfectly his testimony
must have satisfied the jury:


Q. Did you the defendant throw the stone !?
A. saw a stone, and am pretty sure defendant
threw it. Q. Was it q stone OF considerable di.
mensions? A. Why. it was a considerable Of a
stone. @. How large was it? A. should say it
was largish stone. Q. What was its size? A.
Why, it was a szeable stone. Q. Can't you answer
de6nely-how big was ita A. should say it
was stone of some bigness Q You are sngu
lar witness-can' you give the jury some idea Of
the stoneP A. Why. as near as can recollect it
WAS something of stone. Q. Can't you compare
it with some other objecta A. Way, il l was to
compare it, as to give my notion of the stone. |
should say, near as can judge, it was about as
big as piece Of chalk.

ask'd the sage, when wandering afar

What's wisdom HE exclaim'd with fearful eyes,

ask'd the rainbow's changing tnts Of light.
The glorious harbinger Of mercy bright
Aud badc me lull the fearful heart of man."
ask'd the ocean-snd its ceaseless tide
In hollow murmurs to my voice replied
Behold my swelling waves, their ebb and flow.
The hand of Wisdom marks how far they'll 60"
Then pursued the pure, the golden sun,
And found him nearly when his course was done;
90 stay me not" he cried, "check not my pace,
IT'S Wisdom's work run the heavily race!"
ask d the stars 10 track me Wsdoms way,
In The high heav'n Of glory where they lay;
"'Tis Wisdoms path" they cried "thx we have trod,
The path to Wisdom is-the will Of God %
ask'd the moon, the moon that shone afar,
In her pale light within her crescent car
:" Wisdom is knowledge of the hand divine
That bade me be-and PLACID me here to shine"
The silver spheres caught up the heavily song,
Echo'd through endless space it rol'd along;
Angels reJoc'd and hll'd with holy fires,
Tun'd unto Wisdom all their golden Tyres.
+" Wisdoms he influence brightly glowing,
From The Almighty's glory ever flowing!
tn unspotted mirror of is power and might,
The radiance of the everlasting light"
Then earthborn man attune thy sacred yrcp
And join ting chorus of the heavily choir,
L. praise to the great tribune God above,
Whose Willis Wisdom, and whose rod is love.

AS body OF troops passed in review before Bona
parte at the Carousel, his horse became so unruly
that his hat fell off in his exerions to restrain it..
A young soldier, who happened to be near him.
picked up the hat and presentedit it to him. Thank
you captain said Napolean. In what regiment,
sire?' said The young man. A few days after. the
young man, with whose answer Bonsparte was
much pleased, was unexpectedly raised by brevet
to the rank Of captain Of the imperial Guard.

full articles.headline:
TIE LOVER TO HIS MISTRESS, ON THE BRIDAL


EVE.
full articles.article:
EVE.


ByALApr OF NEWPORT, RI.
II is the tender twilight hour,
And glimmering through yon russell bower,
The dying ligh, is seen,
Giving family golden tinge
To the rich mines that deeply fringe
Its Ia'ices of green.
The mellow whistle still is heard,
Of that same dear familiar bird,


We used to love so we'll;
Fer had known the parting pain
d bliss of meeting thee again.


My own dear Rosabee
Ah Love thou never canst forget
When on the green our hamlet met,
And merry pipes were played;
How from the dance we stole away,
And tremblingly led the way


Toyonder lovely shade.
We reach'd the bower, the moon-beams fell
Full on my lovely Rosabelle,


Making the fair more fair.
Like vines round marble pillars hung,
So round her polish'd neck were Aung
The sunny wreaihs OF hair.
Her angel face was tnrnd aside
The blush Of innoc, nee TO hide,


That DER her features stole.
We ne'er before had been alone.
Nor had ever dared TO own


The love that fill'd my soul.
Oh! tell me why in that strange hour,
Beauty had such mysterious po@er'
For though convsed with fears---
With passion not TO be rerressed.
threw myself upon thy breast,


And told my love in tears;
Thou vert subdned; heard thy sohs--
felt thy bcsom's answering throbs--
Thy tears were mixed with mine.
We knew that every doubt was done
Our hearts had melted into one.


On feelings holy shrine
But when the shock that open threw
Our bosoms, to each others view,
In gentle numbers died
The morn Of love--'twas heaven to trace,
just opening in thy besming face,


In all its blushing pride.
Then, Rosabelle. for memory's sake
Our way to thai same bos ser we'll lake,
That saw loves roscate dawn;
Fer this is Courtship's latest eve,
And the. our bridal wrea'hs we'll weave,
Togrsce the coming morn.
All nature seems our bliss to share.
Spirits Of joy are in the air.


They wave their rainbow wings,
And shed, on his auspiciuos night
glow Of pure Elysisn light,


Ger all created things. ROWENA.

Roger. where was If'-At Kenwyn, during di-
vine service, two dogs, one of which the par
sons, were 6gh,ing at the west end Of the Church.
The parson who was then reading the second les
son. rushed out to part them; and on his return,
doubling where he had lef. off, asked the clerk
/" Roger where was 1 - "Why, down parting the
dogs, to be sure" said Roger, to The 10 small
amusement Of the congregation.

full articles.headline:
From the Golumtian Register.
HARTFORD CO 3VENTION,
full articles.article:
Convention; and conformobly TO our annual custom,


tins week make few remarks relative to that


never to be forgotten Assembly. We agree that
on some accounts this task is rather unpleasant :
but we conscentiously believe that proper regard


Tor those republican principles which we have always


cherished. requires the performance at our hands.


We are also ready to admit that many ot the MEM
bers and promoters Of the Hartford Convention pos
sessed talents and integrity and other qualities which


rendered them useful and respectable ctIzeps and
We are willing that their friends should dwell on
their virtues much and az often as they please,
tor we do not undertake TO arragn any thing
than their conduct as connected with this political
project But this we have done, and still do, be-
cause NC have always believed that the Hartford
Convention was . party measure, and INTENDED to
sustain the waning Cause OF federalism; because it
was calculated n its results to be rpinous TO the
peace, unity. and prosperity OF our county and
because the fair fame Of Connecticut, our native
State, was sued by being the spot selected Tor The
Convention to assemble in.


In order therefore that the present generation (f
there are any whose minds are not made up) anc
posterty may be enabled to form correct Judgment
on this subject, We sgaia enumerate some OF the
reasons which led us q, the time, and which have
continued from that day to this to coDst ain US TO
censure this 6old and dangerous scheme. 1t had


long been fore'od BY the emssaries oil Grea' Britain,
that, on the happening Of certain e-en's. Conyen-
tion. like that which assembled at Hartford, would
be held. Those events happened, and the predicted
Convention was hcId-These same cmissaries fore
told that in should be declared against
Engla' d, there would be great opposition to that
war in New England. and Massachusetts would take
he lead in that opposition War was declared and
great opposition arose in the New Eng land States =;
aud the legislature of Massachusetts gave the tone
The ncghboiing States. The members and friends
Of the Convention were the ssders OF the federal
party, who not only opposed the then administration
ut The general government, but they we're strongly
suspected Of being friendly to the British govern
mvni These men had previousl. declared that the
Constitution Of The United States had tailed TO
cure the objects for which formed iney l,ied
to rmbafrass the ed inistraon by ext ring them
selves to transfer the management oil ,he
u the general government 10 the Stale govern ments;
they would not rejoice al he defeats oi the enemy.
nor would they rejoice a. he victories gained by
own army and navy They held the Convention in
secret. and With closed doors and al the time when
the enemy were com ting depredstIons at Ha.re-
de-Grace n.saul'ing Baltimore, pilaging and burn


ing Washington. ard preparing their expedition
against New Oleans; in short, al the very time when


the whole Atlantic coast was threatened with fire
and sword, and the whole northern frontier wa, an
noyed by the ravaees of the enemy and heir In
dian allies. The Convention ton, was held during
war which had been unayoldably declared For tbs
protection OF the lives and liberty Of portion Of our
cixens and for the protection of invaluable rights,
and vast amount of property .whi' war has been
emphaiically styled the second war ol Independence.
And a. every war, however just, necessariIy brings
with it great and distress. this crisis -ezed
by the ederass to regain the standing places, and
influence, which they losing, and force the
government to make a dishonorahle peace. Such
must have been the views Of the friends Of he Con-
venton, for let never be forgotten that the objects
Tor which it was held were mt OBJ all ed. nor have
they since its dissolution made any mpts OBJ
tain the IN but their objec's given over, and
the prospects OF these aspirants vanished soon
the news OF honorable peace reached our shores.
The effects produced by the Convention we he
encouragement Of the enemy, and the sggrava'lon
Of the distresses OF our own citizens. In conciu-
sion, we do not deny that our attention has been
the steadily turned to this subject fof the last
twelve years, because We have always viewed it as
one Of those occur'en' es in the course OF events,
which has worderiul.y tended to put up republic ans
and to pui down federasts and at this time oil day,
who will not admit that this is it should be. for it
seems to have been Of those strong instances in
which much good has come out OF great evil,
but thanks to be given to the friends of the
Convention for that ard all we ask is, that in view
oil the foregoing remarks, every reader should can
didy form such an opinion as III: whole facts and
circumstances warrant


Literary Bargain.- When Fielding had finished
his novel OF Tom Jones, being much distressed he
sold il to an obscure bookseller lor 25l. ON condcn
Of being paid certain given dsy. In the mean
time, he showed the manuscript 10 Thomson, the
Poet, who was Immediately struck Wi its great
merit, and advised Fielding by all means to get ree
from the bargain. which he did without much diff
Guilty, as the bookseller was not capable OF estimat-
ing the value OF his pu chase Thomson recon-
mended the work to Andrew Miller and the parties
met at 4 tavern over beef steak and bottle. Mill
Ter began with saying, Mr.. Fis.dng. always de-
rmine affairs Of this sort at once, and ever
change nv offer, | viii not give one fat thing

full articles.headline: CARRIER PIGEONS.
full articles.article:
eu OF pigeons, as letter carriers s by Ovid. IN h
4" Meamor phoses," who tell Us that Taurssthene
by pigeon stained with purple, gave notice oi b
having been victor at the Olympic games on III
very same day to his father at Egins.


When the city Of Ptolemais. in Syria, was invest
ed by the French and Venitans, and it read
to fall into their hands, they observed pigeon 6y
ing over them, and Immediately conjectured tina,
was discharged with letters TO the garrison On thi
the whole army raising loud shout. SO confounde
the poor erial post, that it fell to the ground
ON being seized, letter was found under its wings
from the Sultan, in which he assured The garrison
that he would be with them in three days, with al
army sufficient to raise the SIEGE" For this let
ter the brssgess substituted another to this purpose
that the garrison must see to their safety, 70
the Sultan had such other ssirs pressing him, tina
it was impossible for him to come to their succour;'
and with this false intelligence they let the pgeor
nee on his course. The garrison. deprived by th
decree OF all hopes Of relief, Immediately surrender
ed. The Sultan appeared on the third day, a:
promised, with q powerful army, and was
little mortified to end the city already In the hands
Of the Christians.


Carrier pigeons were again employed, but with
better success at the siege Of Leyden, in 1875 The
garrison we're, by means Of the Information thu:
conveyed to thcm induced to stand out, till the enc
my, desparing Of reducing the place, Withdrew
On the seige being raised the Prince of Orange or
dered that the pigeons who had rendered such es-
sentipl service should be maintained at the public
expense and that at their Death they should be EN-
bsmed and preserved in the town house, as 6
perpetual token OF gratitude.


In the East. the employment Of pigeons for the
conveyance ofletters is still very common. parties
lsrly in Syria, Arabia, and Egypt. Every Basha~
has generally . basket full # them sent him from
the grand serago, where they bred, and in case
o! any insurrection or other emergency. he is en-
abed, by letting loose two more OF these extraor
dinary messengers convey intelligence to The gov
rrnment long before it could be possibly obtained by
other means.


The diligence snd speed with which these feath
cred messengers wing their course is cxtraor binary
From the instant OF their liberatioD their flight
directed through The clouds at an immense heigh,
to the place OF their destination. They believed
to dart onward 10 a straight line and never descend
except when a. loss for breath, and then they art
to be seen, commonly at dawn Of day, lying on hci
aoks on the ground, with their bills open, suckir.
in with hss,y avidi'y the dew Of the morning. o
their speed the instances related almost incred
Bile.


The Consul of Alexandra daily sends despatche
by these means TO Aleppo in hours, though cour
ers occupy the whole day and proceed with the ut
most expedition from one town to the other.


Some years ago gentleman scot carrier pigeon
from London by the stage cosrh. to bis friend ir
ST. Edmonsbury, together with q note, de,ring tina
the pigeon Two days after their arrival there nigh
be thrown up precisely when the town clock struck
nine in the morning. This was done accordingly
and the pigeon arrived in London, and Rew to the
Bull Inn, Biahopgate street, into the lot,, and
there shown at half an hour past eleven o'clock
having flown seventy two miles in two hours and a
half.


AT Antwerp. in Isl9 one OF the thirty two pigeons
belenging to that city. who had been conveyed to
London, and here let loose, made the transit back
being distance in direct line Of one hundred and
eighty miles, in six hours.


Il 10 through the attachment OF the animals to the
place Of their birth. and particularly to the spot
where they had brought up their young, that they
are thus rendered useful 10 mankind.


When young one flies very hard at home, as il
comes TO its iul strength it is carried in basket
otherwise about half mile from home, and there
turned out-after this. il is carried mile, and ther
two four eight, ten twenty, &C. till at length vii
return from the furthermost parts Of the country.

deemed proper to ascertain the size Of certain

In an action for an assault and battery, il was
deemed proper to ascertain the size Of a certain
stone, with which il was alleged the battery was
committed. For this purpose a witness was called
to the stand, and the following brief report Of his
examination will show how perfectly his testimony
must have satisfied the jury:


Q. Did you the defendant throw the stone !?
A. saw a stone, and am pretty sure defendant
threw it. Q. Was it q stone OF considerable di.
mensions? A. Why. it was a considerable Of a
stone. @. How large was it? A. should say it
was largish stone. Q. What was its size? A.
Why, it was a szeable stone. Q. Can't you answer
de6nely-how big was ita A. should say it
was stone of some bigness Q You are sngu
lar witness-can' you give the jury some idea Of
the stoneP A. Why. as near as can recollect it
WAS something of stone. Q. Can't you compare
it with some other objecta A. Way, il l was to
compare it, as to give my notion of the stone. |
should say, near as can judge, it was about as
big as piece Of chalk.
